page.title: 02High ground around Coniston
page.content:
{UPLAND}More than one third of the block consists of land over 150m. This is open country known as{rough fell, consisting of sparse grasses, often invaded by{bracken,}and rocky ground. Rocky outcrops are known as{crags, with fans of broken stone, or{scree, at their base. The upland is crossed by countless small streams or{becks;}some flow through steep-sided ravines or{ghylls.
{HIGH PASTURE}The{fell wall}marks the upper limit of enclosed rough grazing. Below this are steep fields which have been cleared of stone to build boundary{walls.}Some small areas of {woodland}are present in the high pasture, particularly in the ghylls, where the trees are inaccessible to grazing animals.
